awd_titl_txt: Tripods+X:Res: Collaborative Research: Identification of Gene Regulatory Network Function from Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Molecular and cellular biology are at the forefront of our quest to understand life and improve human health. However, the details of how genes and signals interact in real time to produce cell behavior, are not well understood.  The problem is a lack of approaches that can integrate experimental data into models that describe the important behavior of the system, yet do not describe nonessential details, that would make it too cumbersome to compute in a reasonable time. This project will develop a new set of tools, that can predict the entire range of behaviors of a network of interdependent genes and do it so efficiently that behavior under the effect of a few mutations or behavior of alternative sets of genes can be readily explored. Furthermore, once such a description of behavior of a set of genes is available, it will be shared and used by other scientists. Continuous build-up of these results will rapidly increase their value for data science, cellular biology, and broader science. 
   					
Molecular and cellular biology have witnessed a huge leap forward since science has acquired the ability to sequence genomes. However, while genomes are relatively static, the phenotypes result from the interaction of many genes that are expressed dynamically in time. Furthermore, since phenotypes arise from complex transcriptional networks, where the interactions tend to be nonlinear, data-based models will play a key role in understanding and ultimately controlling these phenotypes. Current modeling techniques, motivated by physics, struggle to bridge a fundamental conflict between low resolution of biological measurements informing model parameter values and the fundamental fact that dynamical systems are sensitive to initial conditions and parameters. This project develops a novel mathematical framework that provides a quantitative description of global dynamics that are compatible with coarse, noisy biological measurements. Combined with computationally efficient algorithms for the construction of databases that capture biologically relevant dynamics of a network, it can become the basis for shared science in the space of gene networks. These tools will be used to construct and validate network models from experimental data, interrogate dynamic behavior of a given network, and compare dynamics summaries across networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

por.por_cntn:
Molecular and cellular biology is an important domain where the ability to sequence genomes of many species has changed how biologists approach questions on understanding the molecular mechanisms influencing evolution and the impact of genotype on phenotype. However, in spite of tremendous promise and advances it is becoming increasingly clear that we are facing important challenges preventing us from collecting full benefits of the genomic revolution. Genomes are relatively static, while the phenotypes of interest result from the interaction of many genes (and their associated proteins) that are often expressed dynamically.  Most of these interactions are inferred and the nonlinearities associated with these these interactions are at best poorly quantified.  This suggests the need for developing coarse, but mathematically justifiable, methods for efficiently characterizing global dynamics given minimal information about the interactions.

Within this project we addressed this need four ways.  First, we extended our software package Dynamic Signatures Generated by Regulatory Networks (DSGRN). The original design was meant to capture the global dynamics of regulatory networks where the regulation was based on transcription factors. However, regulatory networks also involve protein-protein regulation involving kinases and ubiquitin ligases.  Our extended version allows us to model these additional forms of regulation. Second, DSGRN is based on a combinatorial/algebraic topological representation of the dynamics. Nevertheless we proved mathematically that it captures equilibria and their stability for associated systems of ordinary differential equation models with sufficiently steep sigmoidal nonlinearities. Third, on an experimental level we extended these results to global dynamics. More precisely, we observe that using output about global dynamics from DSGRN we could with reasonable probability predict parameter values at which numerical simulations for a corresponding ordinary differential equation model would exhibit similar global dynamics.  Our ongoing work is to replace these exprimental result with theoretical results. Fourth, systems biologist often model regulatory networks using systems of ordinary differential equations with nonlinearities based on Hill functions. We have been developing a numerical library based on these nonlinearities with two goals in mind: (A) to systematize our experimental experiments involving numerical simulations described above, and (B) to be able to perform rigorous mathematical validation of the numerical simulations.

We have started to apply these specific tools to a fundamental biological model, the cell cycle of S. cereviseae. We have postulated a regulatory network (that includes protein-protein interaction), our collaborators have collected time series data and we are in the process of using the extended version of DSGRN to test the validity of our proposed network.

Multiple undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs worked these and related problems. In particular, three students completed their Ph.D.s  and have moved on to academic and industrial jobs. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/25/2022
Modified by: Konstantin M Mischaikow
